text: Hello all! I was just brought on to CIRES/NOAA’s Global Systems Laboratory to work on evaluating Julia in comparison to the existing Fortran and C++ code currently used to run their weather models. I’m new to Julia (and scientific computing), so I’m happy this group is in existence, and hope to get involved/ask questions in due time! :wave:

elements.text: Hello all! I was just brought on to CIRES/NOAA’s Global Systems Laboratory to work on evaluating Julia in comparison to the existing Fortran and C++ code currently used to run their weather models. I’m new to Julia (and scientific computing), so I’m happy this group is in existence, and hope to get involved/ask questions in due time!

text: What an important task! I’ve been battling to convince my colleagues that it is worth it to increase julia adoption in atmospheric sciences. Welcome! Don’t hesitate to post here or in the discourse if you find yourself stuck. You my be interested in checking <#CNK8SLW58|climate> <#C9XBLUCVB|geo> and there are also some people in the zulip

text: Greetings! We're building a climate model in Julia at <https://clima.caltech.edu/>, happy to answer any questions on our experience so far

text: Rob, I'm an incoming NOAA Hollings intern for GOES-R product development and have talked to them about potential use-cases for Julia. Let me know if anything comes up from your end! <mailto:max.hawkins@noaa.gov|max.hawkins@noaa.gov>

text: Awesome! You’ve probably seen it already, but I really liked this talk, on the topic of Julia and climate: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WGe-gYRSM7c>
